Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2006 08:59AM janie44 wrote: Sherry, I am not sure about how long one is at risk for lymphedema. I will try to find out. I had surgery 5/4/04. I started AC for 12 weeks in June of 04 and Taxol for another 12 in August of that year. I remember I first started being wrapped about the time I started rads in December. I had my first visit to the lymphedema clinic while I was still on Taxol. I can pinpoint it to sometime around the last of October or beginning of November. If you fly, I would suggest wearing a sleeve or bandage even if you do not have it. Nobody told me that and I flew home to see my parents in Kingsport that October. Lymphedema showed up shortly afterwards. Have no idea if it had anything to do with it, but those of us who have it are told to be particularly careful to wrap up or wear the sleeve when flying. Of course, we have to wear it all the time now anyway. Everyone have a wonderful Tennessee Thanksgiving! janie

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2007 05:37PM janie44 wrote: Hey ladies, I was wondering how other states were faring with all the new rules.  We are "building a plane while we are flying it" and in a constant state of confusion.  My job has changed drastically.  I am much more involved in Response to Intervention and all it ensues with fewer initial evaluations -- at least at the moment since there is a rule that a child must have at least 12 weeks of interventions before referral to sped.  A lot of teachers are talking about the instructional coach coming to their room to observe and make recommendations etc.  So many changes, and we move to a brand new school (elementary)  in December!  Add that to the mix.  It will all come out in the wash.  Our school is sponsoring part of the Relay for Life walk next week.  I was asked to walk with the survivors.  Have a great weekend ladies.  I will not mention what happened this afternoon (nevertheless go VOls). Janie

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2006 09:37AM janie44 wrote: Hurray! UT is back on a roll! Saw the game. To answer some of your questions, I was dx'ed 3/11/04, stage IIIA, HER2positive+3, ER/PR negative. Dolly Parton and I were born the same year (not too far apart on the map), the year of the boobs, so I had a lot of extra tissue. They did a new procedure where they did a double breast reduction and a lumpectomy and got clear margins. The tumor was 3cm and I had 7/20 positive nodes. They just went back in 10/18/06 and shaped everything up better and repaired damage done by rads. I am pleased with the results as is the plastic surgeon. I am much farther along in my tx than most of you. I have lymphedema and that is a nuisance but tolerable. I also was left with a tremor. Leave it to me to get something weird. Don't know another soul who ended up with a tremor so don't let that worry you. You will not get one. I have a group of friends on this forum that started chemo when I did. We have been through many ups and downs over the last couple of years. Things are looking up for all of us, with a setback here and there, but the worse is definitely over. My hair, brows, lashes etc. are back. My prognosis is much better than it was when I started due to the results in the Herceptin clinical trial. I am 60 years old and have three grown kids (all TN fans although young when we moved). Glad you started the hillbilly thread. Miss my mountains. janie

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2007 09:20PM - edited Sep 29, 2007 09:21PM by janie44 I had ample tissue and had a lumpectomy double breast reduction.  Had clear margins.  dx'ed 3/11/2004  IIIA   HER2+++  ER/PR-  grade 3's  5 cms    7/20 positive nodes     AC /  Taxol  / Herceptin radiation  no recurrence Each of our profiles are so different.  Best wishes during your thinking and with your final decision. janie
Posts.Title: How many have had recurrence after lumpectomy? kidsmom ozzie2

Posts.Content: May 31, 2008 08:32PM janie44 wrote: Mia, On this bc.org website you can go to http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/path_report/ This page has info to read and more info to click on from that page.  It is very thorough in explaining every detail to you and answers many of your questions.  Your profile will be different from everyone elses.  As long as I have been on this board, there are only a couple of more profiles that are very close to mine, but they are not exact fits either.  SO, you can see, that everyone has their own decision to make regarding treatment, surgery etc.  It should be an informed decision that you are part of with input from your oncologist.  In my case, my survival rate was about the same whether I went with the masectomy or the double-breast reduction/lumpectomy.  I went with the latter and they got clear margins.  I have not regretted my decision.  However, each case is situation-specific.  Good luck and God bless you with your decisions. Hugs, Janie

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2009 05:24AM janie44 wrote: Lexi,  Your Dad will be included in my prayers.  Kim, My current onc counts from DX; however, I began TX at Mayo and they count from end of TX.  Therefore, since I began the clinical trial with Mayo, they dictated my appointment schedule and I had the six month schedule for a while longer, but am now only going once a year. Sherri, agree with the early detection comment.  I had annual mammos every year and my lump was discovered during a routine one already at stage 3.  My doc had mentioned having one a few months earlier, but then noticed it had not been a year and said we would need to wait for the insurance to pay for it. Hugs to all, janie

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2008 01:04AM janie44 wrote: From the symptoms / diagnosis section on this site: Inflammatory Breast Cancer Inflammatory breast cancer is a relatively rare but very serious, aggressive type of breast cancer. According to the National Cancer Institute (NCI), 1% to 5% of breast cancer cases in the United States are inflammatory breast cancer. The symptoms of inflammatory breast cancer can include: About 50% of women with inflammatory breast cancer have a lump or a mass in their breast, but it may be difficult to feel since the breast is often bigger and harder than normal. Inflammatory breast cancer is usually categorized as stage IIIB breast cancer because of the possible involvement of the skin, chest wall, or lymph nodes along the breast bone inside the chest wall. If the cancer has spread to other organs, such as the bones, lungs, liver, brain, or to the lymph nodes in the neck, it is categorized as stage IV. Inflammatory breast cancer is hard to diagnose Sometimes inflammatory breast cancer is misdiagnosed as an infection. Because the disease is rare, many doctors have never seen it. Also, it has not been studied as much as other types of breast cancer. An infection is a more common cause of swelling and redness of the breast-that's why doctors think of that diagnosis first. But infection is more likely to happen for a reason, such as breast feeding. Infections go away with proper antibiotic treatment, but inflammatory breast cancer does not respond to antibiotics. A diagnosis of inflammatory breast cancer is made primarily by physical examination, although mammogram, breast MRI, or ultrasound is sometimes used. A diagnosis must be confirmed by a biopsy. However, sometimes a biopsy of inflammatory breast cancer may come back "clear," even as the redness and swelling worsen. So making a diagnosis is very tricky. Treating inflammatory breast cancer involves chemotherapy up front, followed by surgery and radiation. Anti-estrogen and Herceptin (chemical name: trastuzumab) therapy may also have a role. Other forms of targeted therapy, such as Avastin (chemical name: bevacizumab), may be used. The kind and sequence of treatment depends on your individual situation. Best wishes for you and your friend, Janie

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 02:44AM janie44 wrote: Janis and others, This is quote from the HER2support board.  I am sure Tricia would love to pass on her inspirational message to all her sisters: "My good news is that the results today of my 6-month check up show that I am once again NED---and I am dancing! This year marks 23 years since I was first diagnosed with breast cancer, and it is 4 years this month since my last and third diagnosis of mets, this time her2 +. After 6 months on navelbine and 15 months on herceptin, I was and still am NED, and of course my family and I are elated. You may remember that I had had BC in 1985, then spine mets in 1990. I was on tamoxifen for 5 years and in remission for 10 more. After that 15 years I stopped thinking about further mets, until a heart attack in June of 2004 saved my life. Because of it the her2 mets were discovered. The herceptin did cause more heart damage and I had a triple bypass in 2006. I still have cardiomyopathy and congestive heart problem, but no cancer, for which I am most grateful. ANd for those who don't know or don't remember, I will be 79 in December. So hang in there, fellow warriors! I love you all and pray for you! Hugs, Tricia"

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 04:50PM janie44 wrote: Hey ladies,  I am 5 1/2 years out with no evidence of disease.  I was dx'ed stage IIIA with 7 positive nodes.  One swollen node under my arm was as large as my tumor (3cm) and two of the malignant ones were wrapped around the supraclavical.  At one time I was told my cancer was so aggressive that it would be back and it would be stage IV.  That was before Herceptin results changed my prognosis drastically.  The onc I have now is very positive and I only have to go for annual checks.  Mayo just sent me papers to fill out for the clinical trial and I was happy to report no recurrence.  They plan to follow me for 20 years so I guess I need to stick around.  So take heart ladies and dance with NED til the cows come home. At 63, I guess I am already an old lady, but not so much shriveled or wrinkled yet .... but probably just around the corner.  LOL Hugs,,,   Janie

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2010 11:09PM janie44 wrote: When first diagnosed, I was 57 years old and did not know as much as I have learned since then.  My first plastic surgeon (not the last or the one wo did my surgery) told me what she wanted to do which included a mastectomy on one side.  I asked her what the chances were of having a recurrence on the other side.  She said, "Oh, at your age, we don't worry so much about high risks.  Now, if you were 28 years old like one of my patients and had many years ahead of you, then we would think more about risks, but not at your age." Janie
